I have already spelt out that in legislation there will be a maximum of five per cent for strategic ownership. Will they support that? No, they will not. In other words, they want to keep all their options open.

answer.para: We know what Senator Schacht did only last week; he is now prepared to countenance a sell-down to 51 per cent. In other words, they have gone back to where they were before Hobart. That is what this is all about. This is being utterly opportunistic, simply ignoring the fact that our customer service guarantee and a whole range of other changes will be very good news for all Australiansâparticularly Tasmanians, Senator Denman. If you noticed it today, Senator Newman and Mr Fahey put out a press release announcing a pilot program of a new Commonwealth information call centre in Launceston; in other words, more workâmore jobs, that is what you are concerned about. That is why Ansett has a call centre in Launceston: more jobs.

The competition that this other crowd introduced some years ago has resulted in a very significant expansion of jobs in the communications sector, and we are concerned also to ensure that customers are fully protected as well. That is why we have got all those protections in legislation. Why won't you support us in making sure that they stay in place forever?

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that Telstra management in Tasmania have told the workers in the centres I referred to that they will be made redundant at the conclusion of the review? What is the purpose of having a review if the conclusions are already known?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI do not know what review we are talking about, but the preposterous suggestion that something should be retailed third-hand and trotted out in the Senate as though it is gospel because some unionist somewhere told you what they understood to be a message conveyed by management is simply not good enough. Senator Denham, you should not let yourself be put up to ask these questions.
âSenator, the answer should be directed to the chair.

âMadam President, Senator Denham may be one of the very few on that side of the chamber who are not rolled gold unionists, but she has an obligation to think for herself. She ought to get out there and check the facts, not retail a bit of scuttlebutt, and look closely at the legislation. That is what this is all about: protecting customers and making sure that the communications sector is a growth area. Tom Burton is absolutely right. If you had your way, Telstra would be caught betwixt and between. You would have a great Australian company going backwards, all because of ideological opportunism. (Time expired)

âMy question is also to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. I ask the minister, is it not the case that there is a direct conflict between his customer service guarantee and the responsibility of the directors to maximise profits for shareholders? Isn't it also the case that the real reason why services have declined substantially in rural areas is that some 3,000 jobs have been shed in rural Australia? Is it not the case that the fully privatised Telstra plans to shed a further 25,000 jobs over four years? So how can we improve services when there will be few, if any, people out there to deliver them?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âAgain, it is very sad when you only have a little piece of information and you try to slot it into your ideological predilections. You say that Telstra plans to cut 25,000 over four years. They announced about 2Â½ years ago that they were going to reduce their work force by 22,000 over three years. That process is two-thirds complete, and it has been achieved without any expression of angst even on the part of the unions. I have no doubt that this mob over here have been out there trying to whip them up, but they have not.

answer.para: Let me come to the much more important aspect of this whole debate. This is where people like the Democrats really have a lot to answer for. I know you do not want to understand economics, but let me put to you that back in 1991, when Telstra was corporatisedâin fact, it was earlier than thatâI remember the then Senator Gareth Evans put out a discussion paper about GBEs and it was made perfectly plain that Telstra would be expected to operate competitively and commercially. So the fact is that ever then, at least seven years ago, the directors of Telstra have had a legal obligation to ensure that that company is run commercially and in accordance with the Corporations Law of this land. There is no question at all that somehow suddenly they are going to be asked to be able to operate commercially. They were asked by the Labor government seven long years ago to operate commercially, and those directors could find themselves in gaol if they did anything to the contrary.

The reason why that system can work is that, at the same time, you superimpose a raft of social commitments. You have a universal service obligation, you have price caps and you have licence conditions requiring roll-outs of ISDN capability. The customer service guarantee is simply the latest in a long line of legislative overlays. In other words, Telstra is required to operate commercially but subject to the overriding requirements imposed by the parliament to ensure that people in rural and remote areas get the benefits, even though it might not be commercial, and that they get them by a cross-subsidised systemâin other words, an industry levy funded by all the other players.

You know that as well as I do. Even they know it, Madam President. The reason why the Australian Democrats want to ignore that is that they want to play this silly little game of, oh, all of a sudden, with privatisation, the company will have to operate commercially. It is a lie, and you know it. They have always been required to operate commercially. Nothing whatsoever will change as a result of any change of ownership, just as nothing changed when we got the bill through a couple of years ago.

talk.start.para: âHow do you know?

âBecause the obligations are precisely the same. The directors are required to look after the commercial interests of the shareholders to ensure that they get value for money, to ensure that the company is properly and efficiently operated. If we think that over and above that there are obligations that ought to be imposed on Telstra, or any other carrier for that matter, then we do that. We do it by legislation. We have done it time and again. You, of course, would bind them hand and foot to the point where they really could not operate commercially. But we do it in such a way that the company has gone from strength to strength while consumers can still be fully protected.

answer.para: That is the sensible model. That is why this Labor Party privatised every government business enterprise. You are only left with Australia Post and Telstra. We have given a cast-iron guarantee that Australia Post will not be privatised, and the only other company left in the game is Telstra. Mr Beazley was prepared to commit back in 1991 to Telstra being privatised. Oh yes, he was always prepared to make those sorts of promises. He has never gone into the lower house and denied that but instead sneaks around it with all sorts of weasel words. The fact is that Mr Beazley is Australia's greatest privatiser. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you still have the power to direct Telstra, although I ask you whether it is not the case you are trying to give that away. At least if we remain where we are we still have some force to insist. But I do remind you, through you, Madam President, of your words when you said that your customer service guarantee would ensure that `customer service levels are not only maintained, but enhanced'. This simply has not happened. If we move on and fully privatise and you change your customer service obligations again, isn't it more than likely that again Telstra will define them as narrowly as possible? Isn't the likely scenario that we, the taxpayers, will be picking up the cost of ensuring that adequate rural services go beyond the year 2000?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âOf course it does not define the customer service guarantee, we do. The power to direct has been in the act since 1991. The Labor Party never used it, but if Senator Schacht got half a chance he would impose billions and billions of obligations on them to meet his own political agenda in marginal seats. That is not the way to go. The way to go is to ensure that those standards are in place. Telstra tell me that, since the last quarterly survey, the quality of service has risen quite significantlyâ
âWhat!
âI am telling you. These are not published figures.
âHa, ha.

âIf the Labor Party wants to say Telstra is lying, so be itâbut I am expected to take the word of Senator Denman of what some unionist said he heard at a management meeting recently. Madam President, I am telling you that Telstra tell me that, since that last quarterly survey came out, the standard of service has risen significantly in a number of areas. That report was to the end of March. It is now more than three months since that time. (Time expired)

âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Can the minister confirm that, following a cabinet decision in August of last year, the Prime Minister issued a directive that no minister or members of their staff could buy Telstra shares within 90 days of the share offer? Did the Prime Minister write to all ministers setting out this prohibition? Can the minister confirm that this prohibition was deemed necessary to preclude any ministers taking advantage of any inside information that may have come from cabinet or other discussions?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: âI obviously do not report on cabinet determinations or advice given within cabinet, or even on the content of cabinet discussions. Certainly there was guidance, during the course of last year, in relation to the purchase of Telstra shares. I recall in particular the period leading up to the Telstra sale and the obvious need to take great care that there was no conflict of interest or, for your benefit, I will say perceived conflict of interest in relation to that, Senator Ray. There was some discussion about whether there should be, using my language, a `cooling-off period' thereafter. As I did not purchase them, and had no intention of purchasing them, I cannot remember the full details of that.

âI did not ask the leader to reveal cabinet discussions, nor would I ever. My question was simply: was there a cabinet decision? Did the Prime Minister write to ministers and was that passed on to their staff members? Could the minister take that part on notice and give us a quick response on that? While he is doing that, if that was the case he might also confirm, seeing that the stock market float started on 17 November, whether that prohibition went through for the three monthsâthe 90 daysâto mid-February.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: âI will take that on notice and see what I can provide.

âMy question without notice is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is it true that two protesters, after plea bargaining, have been ordered to pay $300 each in the Northern Territory courts this morning to the mining giant, ERA? If so, is this nothing more than blood money being paid to a greedy multinational corporation out of the pockets of impecunious but high principled Australians? Is the minister aware of a call by Northern Territory Police to involve the Federal Police in this contentious issue at Jabiluka? If so, will the minister give an assurance to the Senate that that involvement will be like Federal Police involvement in the Franklin River issue, where the Federal Police were brought in to investigate the extent of destructionâ(Time expired)

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Brown for his question. Senator, as good as the Attorney-General's Department areâand they are a good departmentâand as quick and efficient as they are, with the greatest respect, you are asking a lot to think that they would have a brief in here at lunchtime on something that apparently happened in the Northern Territory court this morning. It is understandable that the Attorney-General's Department does not have staff sitting and watching what is happening in every court around Australia. I will make some inquiries both as to what might have happened in the Northern Territory courts this morning and in relation to the second part of the question, namely whether there has been any request for involvement of Australian Federal Police.

answer.para: Before leaving it at that, I would add that the senator asked a question about blood money being paid to an international company from `impecunious' and `high principled' protesters. I simply make the point that this government has the view that the law is there for you whether you are impecunious or wealthy, and whether you are high principled or otherwise. They are not entitlements to break the law.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the honourable minister if she will confirm that Federal Police will not be involved in this matter unless, as in the Franklin campaign, it is to study the extent of the destructive activity of the bulldozers sent into a national treasure wilderness. Secondly, in response to that answer, is it the minister's view that peaceful protesters ought to be subject to the outrageous Northern Territory laws, which potentially leave them faced with a mandatory two weeks in jail and a potential sentence of seven years for nothing but protesting for what they think is for the benefit of the future of this country?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âI already indicated to Senator Brown that I would make inquiries about any request for the use of the Australian Federal Police. They will only ever be used for proper purposes, I can give that assurance.

answer.para: The senator goes on and asks about my views on the Northern Territory legislation and its application to peaceful protesters. It is very clear to those who support the democratic process that the noise of protest, if you like, is the bell of freedom, and we should all welcome peaceful protest. The point that has to be remembered by peaceful protesters is that they must do so within the law. That just happens to be an inconvenience to some peaceful protesters, but that inconvenience is there. I welcome peaceful and lawful protest on any issue. We should be continually reminded of how lucky we are to live in a country where people can lawfully and peacefully protest. But that right to lawful and peaceful protest is called into question when people do not obey the law. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. How does the minister respond to the case of an unemployed 19-year-old, sharing a flat in Ballarat, who was given two days notice that her newstart allowance would cut out completely on 1 July as a result of the introduction of the youth allowance?

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. This grubby little question time tactic has been tried on a number of occasions in this chamber over the last week, and I again invite you to rule that those questions are hypothetical unless the Senate is given at least a skerrick of evidence to suggest that they are actual. We have had nothing to date from any other questioner and it does not look like we are getting anything from Senator Carr to substantiate this question, either. If that is not the case then it should not be regarded as a genuine question.
âOn the point of order, I have here a letter dated 30 June 1998 detailing the case I am putting to the minister at the moment.
âTable it.

âMadam President, on the same point of order, Senator Alston has taken this spurious point of order on a number of occasions. You have consistently ruled his point of order out of order as having no basis. I would suspect that if you were going to make a ruling you would be consistent with your previous ruling on this matter, and you would certainly wait until the conclusion of Senator Carr's question before you made such a ruling.

âThere is still time for Senator Carr to develop his question, certainly. Hypothetical matters must not be put to ministers and, if the minister feels that it is hypothetical, she does not deal with that part of it. But there may be other parts that she would want to deal with.

âWhat is the 19-year-old going to do to find the $60 a week for rent on her flat, the lease for which runs out in February 1999? Does the minister agree with the advice given to her by Centrelink in Ballarat, which was to go home to her town of Moonambel?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: âSadly, this is the way the opposition operates; and quite improperly, in my view, if they are really serious.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âMadam President, this is a serious matter and I would hope that they would listen in silence.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder!
âThis is another occasion in a matter of days that the Senate has been presented with what appears to be the circumstances of a private individual, asking me for comment upon it.
âHave you ever had a look at what you did when you were in opposition, you hypocrite?
âOrder! Senator Faulkner, withdraw that.
âMadam President, I withdraw.

âLast week, Senator Forshaw also raised a purported case of an individual. I asked him to get to my office and give me the details of that and I would investigate it. He did not do so, and so I had my office contact his office some days later to ask when I was going to get that information because it was very important that I checked it out. I have still not received that information.

answer.para: The shadow minister for social security has also been making claims about how some individual is going to be affected by the youth allowance but, once again, has not come to my office. I do warn honourable senators that there are people taking to the airwaves or, presumably, going to the opposition, who are not necessarily telling the full story.

talk.start.para: âWe want to warn people about you.
âSenator Faulkner.

âI know that the opposition would rather try to shout me down, as they are doing now, but the facts are that three media outlets in the last seven days have highlighted the situation of a family as being affected by the youth allowance. The information that was given to the public about that family was untrue; it was incorrect. I do not make any judgment about why it was, but certainly the information about family income was incorrect and the information about the family entitlements was also incorrect. If the honourable senator would like to give me a copy of that letter, I would be very happy to follow it up. But, in the circumstances I just outlined, I am not prepared to take at face value what people are saying about their circumstances until they are investigated by Centrelink.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would draw to your attention, Minister, that this was a letter sent to Mr Michael Ronaldson, a copy of which has also been supplied to the opposition, dated 30 June. I trust that you will be able to take the matter up with your colleague, who should by now have advised you of the details of this letter. I go on and say that the opposition is not known for using the tactics that saw the Wright family, as used by Senator Vanstone in the past. I would ask, Minister: can you confirm the advice given by Centrelink that this young woman will have to continue to repay a $500 Centrelink approved loan at the rate of $38.50 a fortnight which previously had been taken out of her newstart allowance?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: âPerhaps I will have to re-emphasise for Senator Carr that Centrelink can give you information over the telephone or in person which may or may not be the definitive position. Has that person lodged a form? Has he or she received a determination from Centrelink? It is one thing for a young person to go to Centrelink, give an approximate estimation of their parents' income and fail to mention that there are any siblings who are dependant upon their parents. I will not accept that statement of alleged facts until I have the opportunity to have it checked out with Centrelink as to what information was given to Centrelink and as to whether that is a final determination. It is only on the basis of an application form, for which the decision can be appealed through the normal review process, that we can accept it. I am not prepared to; your colleagues have been playing games. Other people have been giving information that was not accurate and I am not prepared to accept yourâ(Time expired)

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Given recent public discussion in Australia of immigration policy, and particularly the issue of the number of migrants that Australia should accept each year, will the minister inform the Senate of the government's approach to this issue of vital importance to all Australians? Will the minister also advise how this contrasts with the previous Labor government's record and with other views in the community on this issue.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Payne for the question. This government has very substantially reformed and repaired immigration policy since taking government in 1996, after 13 years of Labor. We have eliminated a number of rorts and abuses, such as sham marriages, abuse of legal process and failure to enforce compliance breaches in the immigration area. Very importantly, we have changed the balance of the intake to reflect the current needs of the Australian economy, giving much greater weight to migrants who are able to contribute to the Australian economy.

answer.para: Under Labor's policy, family reunion migrants outnumbered skilled migrants by roughly two to one. Under this government, that balance has changed very dramatically from two to one to fifty-fifty. That is, we have rebalanced the program, and skilled migrants now form about 50 per cent of our annual intake of migrantsâand we believe that the community welcomes that change.

This very positive approach to immigration policy is in stark contrast to the ragbag of nonsense policies that come out of David Oldfield's One Nation policies. Those policiesâif one might refer to them as suchâare an anathema to the overwhelming majority of Australians who recognise that Australia is a nation built on migration: we owe everything we have built to it, and our future depends on it. It is also a very stark contrast to the approach of Labor, which has consistently for many, many years cynically used immigration policy.

Last week I reminded the Senate that the coalition parties, the parties on this side of the chamber, were the first to welcome Indo-Chinese refugees to Australia in significant numbers, and that Labor opposed our welcoming approach. Since that time, my attention has been drawn to what Mr Clyde Cameron has had to say about Mr Whitlam, the then Prime Minister, who apparently turned to his foreign affairs minister in the last months of the Labor government in 1975 and said, `I'm not having hundreds of'â`delete' or a few dots I had best put thereâ`Vietnamese balts coming into this country with their religious and political hatreds against us.' That is a clear indication of the sort of cynical attitude that Labor has always had to immigration policy.

Labor has real form on immigration policy. Yesterday, former Senator Evans was asked a question on this issueâand he ducked for cover. He said, `I'm not going to be drawn on numbers.' He would just say that Labor was in favour of strong, continuing immigrationâand that is it.

So this is another area where Labor will hold a discussion after the election. They are not going to make decisions before that might let the electorate see what they are going to do; they are just going to have another discussion after the election. This is what Labor says they were going to do on native titleâand thank heavens we have fixed that. That is what they are going to do to handle the Asian crisis; they are going to have a chat about it after the election. If we had not fixed the waterfrontâ

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I raise a point of order. The standing orders make it quite explicit that, in answering a question, a senator shall not debate the question. We had earlier today the spectacle of Senator Hill debating a question about what Labor might do, he asserting Labor shall do it. We now have another spectacle of another minister saying what Labor shall do. That is surely debating the question and, according to the standing orders, is thus out of order.
âDebating is certainly out of order. But the minister, I think, is dealing with the question that was put to her and answering it. Senator Vanstone represents the area, Senator.

âI do understand Senator Cook's embarrassment at the policy-free zone on the other side of the chamber; I clearly understand thatâan absolute policy-free zone. Discussion after the election means back to the old practices of short, cynical manipulation; cronyism; the backroom deals and branch stacking that happened in relation to immigration policy over thereâand you ought to know all about it. You do not have to read all about it; you can watch it on televisionâall the branchstacking in relation to ethnic groups that goes on in Victoria.

answer.para: Everyone needs to be reminded of what the Australian said in 1975: that Senator Bolkus's performance as Minister for Immigrationânot here todayâ`falls short of the high standards reasonably expected of holders of ministerial office'. That is what you will go back to, if Australia were ever to re-elect a Labor government.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm information provided by DEETYA that funding for job matching or FLEX 1, which was originally estimated to be $222 million, is now expected to total $183 million, and that funding for jobsearch training or FLEX 2, which was originally estimated to be $50 million, is now expected to total $37.7 million? Doesn't this mean that the government, at a time when it has failed to make any inroads at all into unemployment, is planning to cut a further $51.3 million from a budget for labour market programs which has already suffered a cut of $1.8 billion?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: âI am not aware of the figures that are alleged by Senator Collins. But I can tell the Senate that there is no intention to cut back in relation to the jobs network program that we have introduced. This is one of the greatest reforms that this country has seen. It is a reform involving over 300 organisations. It is not being cut back to just a few job agencies, as Senator Mackay alleges. We are providing job seekers in this country with a number of choices they have never had before. We are offering them more job sites to go to than before. There are now in the region of 1,500 job sites. In fact, our referrals for intensive assistance are now up to 134,000. That is way in excess of the 125,000 target we had for the end of June.

answer.para: This program is going very well. We have had reports from job providers that things are going well out thereâbut they just wish that the opposition would be a little more positive about this; they just wish that media reports would be a little more positive about this and look at those providers which are getting on and providing referrals for those people who need them.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. On the assumption that DEETYA will confirm to the minister what it has already told the Senate estimates committee in his presence, will the minister acknowledge that this decision to further cut labour market funding is about saving money not improving services? Minister, it is a bit difficult to be optimistic about a further cut of $51.3 million on top of $1.8 billion.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: âIt is very difficult to answer any question on the assumption of anything. Again, it is another hypothetical question that the opposition is putting. What I can say is this: what this government is about is improved services which give job seekers in Australia a great advantageâfrom job matching, which was the former FLEX 1, right through to job intensive assistance. What we are on about is giving people choice and giving competition in the job provision marketplace to give those job seekers more opportunity and more success.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Is it the case that there is a federal police investigation under way in the minister's department at present because of alleged leaks to the Democrats? Who ordered the investigation? Was it the minister or was it the departmental secretary? Did the minister insist on this investigation to intimidate and punish his staff because he was fed up with being embarrassed? Wouldn't the minister rather have public servants who give frank and fearless advice than intimidated staff forced to help the government to cover up its assault on the environment?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: âPublic servants have to obey the law as well.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Again I ask: who ordered the investigation? Was it the minister or the head of the department? Does this investigation not reflect badly on the minister's management of his department that his professional staff feel so compromised? Is it not the case that the minister spreads the rhetoric of protecting the environment but in reality decisions coming from the minister's department are more and more environmentally destructive? Is it not also the case that the staff morale in his department is at an all-time low? Hasn't the minister himself created the circumstances for leaks by making bad decisions, routinely evading questions, fudging public statements and generally treating questions in the parliament and in the media with contempt? Hasn't the minister created this environment of distrust? Isn't he reaping exactly what he has sown?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: âYou could not push much more into a minute, I don't think.

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. My understanding of the standing orders is that a supplementary has to come from the answer to the question that was asked initially. I cannot ascertain in any form how this question could relate at allâ
âA series of questions.

âA series of questions, yes. Thank you, Senator Lightfoot. I cannot ascertain how this series of questions can relate at all to the answer that was given by Senator Hill. Madam President, I respectfully ask you to rule this question out of order because it has nothing whatsoever to do with the answer that was provided by the Leader of the Government, Senator Hill.
âPart of it I thought reiterated the initial question, and there were some other matters. If Senator Hill has anything he wants to add, I am prepared to let him have the minute to do so.
âI remember in opposition that I used to feast on leaks from the foreign affairs department.
âThat's why you are so skinny!
âNow that I am in government I am putting on weight. Perhaps it was the then Minister for Defence feasting on leaks from his own department. That would be a personal reflection so I withdraw that.

answer.para: I have to say that we have set the departmental officials within the environment department a very demanding agenda. The work that was required to set up the Natural Heritage Trust and to put it into practice required an enormous amount of work. The work that we have expected of them in relation to the government's greenhouse agenda, the work that was set in relation to not only the drafting of the most comprehensiveâanyway, they are doing a great job and they deserve a lot of credit. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
âby leaveâI seek leave to table a letter which I was invited to table earlier in question time.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âOn 30 June I was asked a question by Senator Lundy in my capacity representing the Attorney-General, and I have an answer which I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as followsâ
QUESTION FROM SENATOR LUNDY TO SENATOR VANSTONE, MINISTER FOR JUSTICE, REPRESENTING THE ATTORNEY-GENERAL IN THE SENATE QUESTION TIME: 30 JUNE 1998

Has the Attorney-General's Department been advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of its concerns that the Government's policy on parallel importation could illegitimately allow importation of pirate Cds into Australia?
ANSWER
No. The Attorney-General' s Department advises that it has not been so advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Has the Attorney-General's Department been advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that the Government policy could also breach TRIPS and Australia's general obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation?
ANSWER
No. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not advised that the policy of allowing parallel importation of legitimate goods would breach TRIPS or the WTO Agreement.

Advice of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was sought in relation to possible amendment of the Copyright Amendment Bill (No 2) 1997, which implements the Government' s policy. The advice provided has supported amendments to the Bill that have now been made public and which further ensure that the Bill could not be said to breach TRIPS or the WTO Agreement by reason of allowing importation of pirated Cds or discriminatory treatment. The advice was based, and sought, on the premise that the Bill, in implementing the Government' s policy, had to be able to withstand these objections.

Does the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's advice also suggest that an international challenge to the Government's policy if implemented, from either the US or the European Union is a realistic possibility?
ANSWER
No. The advice provided does not suggest that the policy, if implemented as proposed by the Govern ment, faces a realistic possibility of successful WTO challenge from the US or the EU.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âOn 12 May in my capacity representing both the Attorney-General and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs I was asked two questions by Senator Harradine concerning legal aid for asylum seekers. In relation to one of the questions by Senator Harradine the answer was given on 25 May on advice from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department. I have subsequently been advised that that answer is incorrect or has some incorrect information in it. The corrected answer is now available and has already been given to Senator Harradine. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard that corrected answer.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ

para.inline: CORRECTED ANSWERS TO QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE

speech.para: Will there be a guarantee that there will be no diminution in the amount of funds available to those asylum seekers who, on the face of it, have genuine claims and who have suffered persecution and require that sort of advice in order to negotiate the complex legal system that Australia has adopted?
Answer

The Government is committed to ensuring that all asylum seekers found to be refugees are treated in accordance with Australia's international obligations under the Refugees Convention and Protocol. It is not accepted that meeting this commitment requires lawyers to assist asylum seekers with their applications.

Every asylum seeker in detention will have access to assistance at Government expense to help them make an application for a protection visa. Assistance will also be provided to those protection visa applicants in the community who are experiencing financial hardship, or have suffered torture and trauma and have cases of merit. The assistance is provided under contract by registered migration agents and some legal aid commissions.

The service provided is immigration advice and assistance for applications at the primary stage and the review stage. Legal aid however, continues to be available for matters where there are differences of judicial opinion which have not been settled by the Full Court of the Federal Court or the High Court, or where proceedings seek to challenge the lawfulness of detention.

The changes made to the guidelines for legal aid funding in refugee matter recognises that Australia has a world class system for determining claims for Australia' s protection and that genuine refugees need only be able to relate their story to officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs or to the Refugee Review Tribunal. This is not "a complex legal system" and legal expertise is not necessary in order for applicants to present their claims for protection.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked today, relating to Telstra.

We had here today the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) showing the first genuine signs of being rattled by the fact that in the coalition there is growing dissent from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his policy to fully privatise Telstra. We have seen over the last week members of the National Party both in this place and in the House of Representatives on the public record openly disagreeing with the Prime Minister and with the minister on the full privatisation of Telstra. They are reflecting the panic in the National Party that overwhelmingly their own voters, their own supporters in rural Australia do not support the full privatisation of Telstra and want to maintain Telstra in two-thirds public ownership, which it is at the moment.

Every published opinion poll taken since the Prime Minister announced his policy on 15 March to fully privatise Telstra has shown at least a two to one, if not a three to one, majority opposed to any further sale of Telstra shares. So it is not surprising that the National Party and some rural Liberal backbenchers are asking and demanding that the Prime Minister have meetings with them to change the policy. It went so far last week that the member for Dawson, Mrs Dee-Anne Kelly, got up in the parliament and, on the record, said that she would cross the floor and vote against the privatisation of Telstra because that is what her constituents wanted.

We have seen the government's policy on Telstra unravelling. One of the reasons it is unravelling is that, when the Prime Minister made this announcement on 15 March to fully privatise Telstra, he had never even been to cabinet with a cabinet briefing seeking the views of cabinetâhe announced it unilaterally. As I understand it, not even the minister for communications was involved in discussions with the Prime Minister, who at that stage was desperate to make an announcement to take attention away from the problems Senator Parer had given his government at the time of the Liberal Party convention in Brisbane.

Ordinary Australians understand that a fully privatised Telstra will not provide a commitment to services in rural areas. Of course, the cat was belled this weekend on this issue in an article in the Australian Financial Review on Saturday, which I have heard no-one deny, that says:

Telstra Corp's board has warned the Federal Government that it may not be able to support a major upgrade of service to the bush, saying such a scheme could harm its financial performance and sharemarket value.

We have it there: the board is interested only in the value of the shares and the bottom line profit; it is not interested in providing telecommunication services to all Australians no matter where they live. The Labor Party makes it clear that we have never favoured the sale of Telstra. We understand that 99 per cent of telecommunications services in regional and rural Australia are provided by Telstra, and will be provided by Telstra for the foreseeable future.

The public has every right to be cynical of the promises made by the minister and the government that there will be an improved customer service guarantee. In March of this year, the Telecommunications Performance Monitoring Bulletin was published, causing considerable embarrassment to the minister. Before it was actually tabled, he had announced he was going to increase some marginal penalties on Telstra and carriers if they did not meet certain standards demanded by people in the bush. I want to point a couple of these out. The percentage of new services connected on or before the agreed commitment date, in the 12 months to March this year, fell from 81 per cent to 64 per cent. In the first full period of privatisation, it went down nearly 18 per cent. The percentage of faults cleared within one working day of notification in the country fell from 69 per cent to 59 per cent. The percentage of faults cleared within two working days of notification in the country fell from 87 per cent to 77 per cent. These are just a few of the examples that show that the privatisation of Telstra is cutting off services to the bush. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThat is a bit rich coming from the ALP, bearing in mind their record in areas such as the privatisation of public companies. If we look back to the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas, everyone will recall that they went to elections and swore on their hearts, `No, we will not privatise these companies. We will not sell off public assets.' I am sure Senator Carr, in particular, was perturbed by the fact that his so-called `socialist government' kept doing this, year in, year out.

speech.para: It is absolute humbug and hypocrisy for them to oppose what is happening with Telstra at the moment because, if Australia had been unfortunate enough to continue with a Labor government in 1996, they would have been flogging off Telstra at this stage. If they had followed former Prime Minister Keating's view on it in cabinet, they would have sold the lot in one hitânone of this one-third and then the rest; they would have sold the lot in one hit.

They would have done it for the reason that we and countries right around the world do itâbecause these are business operations, these are commercial operations. They have always been required not only to run their business but to return a dividend. Governments have taken this money out and put it back into their budgets. When you look at the balance between selling Telstra and what we get in return to reduce public debt, the interest we save versus the dividend it would have returned otherwise, you find that you come out in front doing it the way that we are doing it at this time.

Of course, you must set up universal service obligations and customer service guarantees. That is exactly what this country has done, as other countries around the world have done. The important thing is that we have a communication market that is highly competitive, that drives costs down, that drives prices down and that delivers real dividends back to the customers. That is what we are setting up under this systemâthat is what Labor would have set up. But we have set up what is probably the best system of guarantees anywhere in the world for customers, particularly for those in the bush.

The Australian Financial Review of 6 July published an article on what our approach is doing for people in the bush. It points out that 93 per cent of the country gets these sorts of services. In comparison, rural connections in the United States are running at only 85 per cent. The Australian Financial Review article notes that 93 per cent of rural customers in Australia currently have access to broadband digital services such as ISDN, compared to 80 per cent in the United States and 70 per cent in Canada.

We have been setting up this system so that top benefits are given back to rural customers in Australia and they get high quality service. What they have now compared with what the Labor government had set up previously is a competitive market that has been made more competitive since deregulation in the middle of last year. That more competitive market will deliver lower prices and other benefits. Some of those other benefitsâI am sure the people who work in Telstra are really very chuffed with thisâinclude the opportunity for people to be part owners of Telstra. The changing balance in the work force across different companies means reduced numbers working for Telstra. As the minister said, there has been 14 per cent growth in this sector in Australia. Why are people not complaining? Because there are jobs in this sector. If the jobs are not in Telstra, they are in other private companies. This is the most dynamic and expanding market in Australia.

We have set up a much more competitive market. The full sale of Telstra means that a great dividend is returned to the government. With that dividend, the government can provide infrastructure in rural Australia. We can guarantee universal service obligations and retire public debt for Australia. It is a great program and something that all Australians should support. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the motion to take note of the various answers provided by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) at question time today concerning Telstra. I rise to my feet as a senator for Tasmania, a state which the government advised would be substantially better off as a result of the one-third privatisation of Telstra. The reality is that Tasmania is not. I noted with some interest that, for the second time in a row, the minister was unable to answer questions with regard to his commitment of an additional 170 jobs to be created in the state of Tasmania. The reality is that not only have those jobs not been created, but there has been a substantial diminution of jobs in Tasmania and in the level of service there.

speech.para: What was the minister's response to my question? He said that it was not his commitmentâhe really ought to knowâbut Telstra's commitment. He said, `Go and ask Telstra.' I notice in the same response to Senator Schacht that the minister quoted extensively from private figures which were not tabled. How on earth are we supposed to know? He said that it was not his commitment but Telstra's commitment. He says this, on the one hand, in terms of the commitments and guarantees that he gave to Senator Harradine over the one-third privatisation of Telstra.

However, on the other hand, the very same minister says, `Trust me. I'm from the government. I guarantee you that there will be no cutbacks in services in regional Australia and that there will be no cutbacks in jobs.' How on earth can we believe him? How on earth can the people from my home state of Tasmania believe it when the empirical evidence is there to be seen? The reality is that the state of Tasmania, which is supposed to have done well out of the deal with Senator Harradine, has gone backwards in both the number of jobs created and the services supposedly created.

Let us look at it. Not only has the government not honoured its commitment to Senator Harradine in terms of the 170 additional jobs being created but, as was pointed out by Senator Denman, we have upwards of an additional 80 jobs being lost. The people who provide those services have been told that they have about 12 months before their jobs will go. That is another 80 on top of the 179 already lost. So much for the 170 jobs that were supposed to have been created. All I can say is that if this is a state that is supposed to have done well out of the one-third privatisation of Telstra, I can only guess what on earth is happening throughout regional Australia. We know what is happening because we have been told about it not by people on this side of politics but by those in the National Party. For example, the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) has indicated that she may be prepared to cross the floor with regard to it.

Let us also examine the minister's response. He says, `You don't have to have 170 additional jobs being created in Telstra because they will be created in the private sector.' I am here to tell the Senate that that has not happened in Tasmania, which has an unemployment rate of approximately 11 per cent. There simply has not been a pick-up in job creation elsewhere in the telecommunications industry in aggregate in this state. It is just not going to happen without the retention of two-thirds of Telstra by the government and an interventionist approach to ensure that rural and regional Australia has access to the service that it ought to have, not simply the services that this government believes it should have.

For the information of the Senate, and in the time remaining to me, I want to talk about a very, very sad article that appeared in the Mercury the other day about a family in Electrona, which is probably half an hour outside Hobart, whose house caught alight. They did not have the telephone on, so they rushed to the nearest telephone box, the only one in Electrona, but the telephone was out of order. It had been reported out of order two days beforehand. They had to then drive another half hour to the nearest town of Snug to ring the fire brigade. In the meantime, their house burnt down.

If government members seriously believe that this represents an increase in the standard of services to regional Australia, I would like them to tell it to that family, which now has nothing. Their house burnt to the ground and they now have nothing because the only public telephone box in the town of Electrona was actually out of order. This sort of thing is becoming commonplace in my home state of Tasmania. I implore Senator Harradine, when he comes to cast his vote, to vote in the interests of the state of Tasmania and to ensure that Telstra remains in public hands.

talk.start.para: âThe difference between the Australian Labor Party and the coalition is that Labor Party members enter into these debates on the basis of information given to them by the unions. Those of us on this side know about this issue because some of us actually live in the bush. Madam Deputy President, you live in a large provincial city.
âI live in Tasmania.

âYou live in a capital city. I live in a small country town, so I know first-hand what this is all about. I know what telecommunications are like. I do not have the union ringing me up and telling me the facts; I know them. I live in a small country town with less than 10,000 people in the electorate of Dawson. I have a couple of phone lines into my house. I have a computer that is connected to email to keep me in touch with Canberra and Townsville, where my office is. I also have a laptop computer which plugs into a mobile phone. All those work tremendously from a small country town in North Queensland.

speech.para: I have got to say that, right around Australia, telecommunications have never been as good as they are now. They have been improving since this government came to power because we understand and care about what people in the bush want and need. I agree that it can always be better. But, under our government, with the privatisation of Telstra, the people who work there have a new enthusiasm. The services to those of us who live in the country have improved tremendously. They will get better. Senator Tierney lives out of the capital city. Senator Heffernan lives in the bush. We understand. We do not just listen to what the unions tell us, Senator Carr. But there can be improvements, and we acknowledge that. Perhaps the quality of the basic telephone service could be better. Perhaps we could get better access to advanced services. Perhaps infrastructure and employment needs to be looked at. But we have already done a lot of things.

talk.start.para: âCockies' corner, what do they say?
âOrder! Senator Carr!
âThe union bullyboys do not worry me, Madam Deputy President, so do not bother calling him to order. It just shows what the unions are all about.

speech.para: We understand these things. Already a lot of work has been done. The universal service obligation has been upgraded, resulting in significantly shorter minimum connection times for new customers. A major review is going on incorporating a data capability in the USO. We are getting a tougher customer service guarantee obligation. The minister quite clearly pointed out all these things in question time. There is an effective extension of the untimed local call rights via a rebate to those people who do not currently have this option. There are continuing price controls on Telstra.

We are doing the right thing. We are selling a public telecommunications company and we are using the money to reinvest in other parts of Australia. The first tranche of the sale of Telstra enabled us to retire a hell of a lot of public debt. It also enabled us to make an unprecedented investment in the natural capital of this nation in the form of the Natural Heritage Trust. We have been able to put money from that telecommunications business into our natural heritage in what I suggest is a far better investment for the people of Australia. We have, as well, retired a lot of debt.

What we will do with the proceeds of the sale of the balance of Telstra has not yet been finally determined, although the Prime Minister has said most of it will be used to pay off foreign debt run up by the Labor Party over a number of years, and we will be doing that. That is, of course, good for Australia because the interest that we now pay to overseas lenders will be retained in Australia. We will be able to use all that money that previously went out of Australia for the good of Australia. The regulatory regime in telecommunications will, in fact, enhance Australia's ability to do these things. That is, in my viewâand obviously it is the view of most Australiansâthe way it should be done: a business is sold, the money is invested in better things and the government regulates the way it should to make sure everyone is looked after.

It amazes me that, in the political business, the Labor Party, One Nation, the Democrats and the Greens all agree on many things, and opposition to the privatisation of Telstra is one of them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe partial privatisation of Telstra was secured after the purchase of votes in this place involving arrangements for disproportionate amounts of money from an infrastructure fund to go to Queensland and to Tasmania. That deal involved the establishment of arrangements whereby it was said that 170 extra jobs would be guaranteed in Tasmania. On 11 December 1996, Senator Colston was quoted as saying that the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston, and the Chief Executive of Telstra, Mr Frank Blount, had promised him that Telstra jobs in rural Queensland would be reduced by only 3.4 per cent by June 1999.

speech.para: This is completely contrary to what we were told here today: that this commitment was entered into only by Telstra and not by the minister. We can see that, at the time, the statements were very different. The facts are now emerging; not from union sources, Senator Ian Macdonald, not from your National Party mates, who are in absolute uproar over the consequences of the proposal.

talk.start.para: âAddress the chair, please, Senator Carr.

âWe have performance reports for Telstra itself from the Senate estimates committee which demonstrate that 1,313 jobs in Queensland were lost over the last year alone, between March 1997 and March 1998. My recollection of the figures at the time the Telstra bill was considered for the first time by this parliament is that 12,263 people were employed by Telstra in Queensland. Given those figures, there has already been a 10.4 per cent drop in employment in the whole of Queensland.

speech.para: If we look at the rural employment situation in country towns, 390 positions were removed from Telstra as part of the overall bid to remove one-third of the workers in Telstra: 390 jobs out of the 3,260 that once were employed by Telstra in country Queensland. There has already been an 11.9 per cent drop in employment in Queensland. The commitment, the promise, that was given was that there would be only a three per cent drop by 1999. Already there has been in excess of a 10.4 per cent reduction in jobs across the state of Queensland, and a reduction of 11.96 in rural Queensland. A similar pattern emerges in Tasmania. There has not been an increase of 170 positions. There has, in fact, been a decline of 147 positions. The same pattern occurs in Victoria: 3,241 jobs were removed in the 12-month period between March 1997 and March 1998.

It is little wonder that, since one-third of the work force of Telstra was removed, there has been a substantial drop in the service levels performed by that company. I find it amazing that anyone could challenge this proposition. A one-third drop in the work force leads to a substantial drop in service to customers. It makes sense, surely. Why is that? It is because the commitment by the Telstra management is not now to consumer services or community service obligations; it is to the shareholder. The directors' primary concern now is the private shareholders. Their primary concern is not the 18 million Australians who actually own Telstraâor the two-thirds of it still in public ownershipâbut those one million or so who own a third.

What is the real commitment here? It is to make sure that the unit costs per line are kept down by reducing the number of workers available so as to keep the share price up. Under a privatised Telstra, the real commitment is to the private share ownersânot to the community, not to this country as a whole. The philosophy on which the Liberal Party is based is private profit over the benefits of the community at large.

What better example could you find of that simple philosophy than what is occurring in Telstra. It is not only the union saying there has been a massive drop in the standards of community service obligation and a massive drop in customer service obligation, but it is now a government body. For two successive quarters the ACA has been saying there is a dramatic decline in the services provided to consumers in this country by Telstra, directly resulting from the decline in the number of workers employed by Telstra to do the job. Why does that surprise anyone? Why do we accept for a moment the nonsense that is trotted out by this minister when he blames it variously on the weather or on remoteness? We are talking about service declines in Victoria. That is an outrageous proposition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is interesting to follow Senator Carr in a debate. He should go back to stacking ALP branches and trying to rehabilitate Joan Kirner's political career, because it was a complete and utter diatribe. Today the Senate is sitting alone, and the nation's media is at our beck and call. The Labor Party has completely ignored the great issues of tax, the waterfront and Wik. Instead, we had Senator Schacht getting up and speaking on the sale of Telstra and its effect on regional Australia.

speech.para: This is from a party that does not even support us on the community service guarantee. This is from a shadow minister who hardly takes it seriously. I am always amused by Senator Schacht, who frequently has a smile on his face. It reminds me of the story told by Bob Hope about why Jimmy Carter seemed to smile a lot. According to Bob Hope, `The reason he is smiling a lot is because he has realised his administration is a bit of a joke.' The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, is still waiting for Senator Schacht's submission on the Mansfield inquiry. I do not know whether he ever submitted oneâI do not think he did.

This is a thoroughly opportunistic role being played by the Labor Party just as they are doing for the rest of privatisation. You cannot believe a word that the ALP says on the sale of Telstra. They wanted to sell it in opposition and would do so if ever they were elected again. The difference is that by selling it we will reduce the government debt that we inherited from Labor. We have also said that we would not sell it without seeking the endorsement of the Australian people via election. We say what we are going to do.

Quite simply, the government understands and shares the concerns of many people in regional Australia about telecommunications services. Being properly provided with telecommunications leads to being situation neutral for those who live in regional Australia. These concerns principally relate to the quality of their basic telephone service, access to advanced services, as well as concerns about infrastructure and employment.

In part, these have been addressed by a framework of measuresâand there are a lot more to comeâincluding an already upgraded universal service obligation. This guarantee of access to the standard telephone service is known as the universal service obligation. The net cost of providing it to Australians in regional areas is funded by a levy on Telstra and all other telecommunication carriers. This arrangement will continue to apply and be enforced regardless of who owns Telstra. One aspect of the universal service obligation is that the cost of installing and maintaining a phone line in unprofitable areas of Australia is subsidised by phone users in other parts of Australia.

Also, there will be an upgrading of the universal service plan containing significantly shorter minimum connection times for new customers, a major review into incorporating a data capability into the USO and a tough customer service guarantee obligation, which is absolutely essential. Thanks to the coalition, all phone companies are required by law to provide a customer service guarantee. If a phone company offers an inadequate service in line installation or repair, its customer is entitled to receive financial compensation, whether in regional or metropolitan Australia. This law will be maintained and, if necessary, will be strengthened.

There will also be continuing price controls on Telstra. There will be an effective extension of untimed local calls by giving a rebate to those people who do not currently have this option, requiring Telstra to make ISDN available to at least 96 per cent of the population. In addition, the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, which was made possible by the sale of the first tranche of Telstra, will be used for networking the nation. There will also be ongoing quality of service monitoring arrangement backed up by reserve ministerial licensing powers.

The introduction of an open environment to new competitors, which has already seen the likes of Iridium take out carrier licences principally to service rural and regional Australia, will probably demonstrate that the traditional telecommunications solutions are not the only ones for Australia and that market-driven innovation is also an important part of the delivery of service. There is no doubt about that. Technology is changing so rapidly in this area that many of the concerns of regional Australia will be met by the competition from the carriers. We will also be looking to further enhance this framework in the context of the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 . (Time expired)

subdebate.2.para: Motion (by Senator Calvert, at the request of Senator Patterson)âby leaveâagreed to:

That the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee be authorised to hold an in camera hearing during the sitting of the Senate on Thursday, 9 July 1998 from 9.30 a.m. to take evidence for the committee's examination of Telstra's annual report.

subdebateinfo.title: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The committee is considering the message from the House of Representatives concerning the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] , and the motion moved by the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin, that the committee does not insist upon its amendments disagreed to by the House and agrees to the amendments made by the House.

âThe quest for a workable solution to native title following the High Court decision on the Wik case in December 1996 has been long and harrowing for all those concerned. We are familiar with, if not always adept at, grappling with issues like taxation, social security, unemployment and trade, and native title has been an original concept challenging the political system.

speech.para: Throughout the debates and negotiations the National Party has stood up strongly for the bush in their need for certainty and stability in order to make their great contribution to this country. Native title has been one of the main concerns in the bush. They believed in the original proposition that native title would not be placed on pastoral leases. That was the original position and then came the 10-point plan and this compromise signed off on by the National Farmers Federation, the mining industries and all the conservative state governments.

While people the bush are certainly not happy with this compromise, they are realistic because it is better than having nothing there at all. The people in the bush have been angry, frustrated and wary, but they are resigned to a compromise in order to get their great industries of agriculture and mining moving again.

No-one believes that this is the end of the controversy of native title, but it is a long way towards a beginning for Australia post-Wik. Once the High Court handed down its Wik decision, the die was cast for further legal challenges. The decision by its very nature created complex questions which will be played out in our courts for some considerable time.

The nature and definition of native title is a substantial issue yet to be explored, let alone resolved. Legal challenges will therefore be with us for a long time. This is not due to whether we have a 10-point plan, the extinguishment of native title or a 50-point plan; it is simply due to the need to create precedents to flesh out the High Court's original decision. No doubt there will be challenges by indigenous Australians, the mining industry and also by rural and primary industries.

Under the agreement reached between the government and Senator Harradine, the right to negotiate on pastoral leases is removed, with native title holders being given the same rights as pastoralists. Renewal of pastoral leases will not be subject to the right to negotiate. Leaseholders will be able to carry on their full range of farming activities without concern about the effect of native title. There will be some problems if there is to be upgrading, but that was always the case under the 10-point plan.

Ambit and overlapping claims will be discouraged through a higher threshold test. All existing claims will have to go up against this new, tougher test. Native title holders have the right to be consulted regarding mines and compulsory acquisition on pastoral leases and in towns, but this is not a right of veto above the rights enjoyed by other Australians.

The Native Title Act as a whole is no longer subject to the Racial Discrimination Act, which would have caused legal chaos. Instead, the RDA is only relevant to the performance of functions and the exercise of powers authorised by the Native Title Act itself.

The sunset clause has been removed. This is a significant concession from people whose homes and businesses lie in claimable areas. Most understand that native title rights can be sought at common law without the imposition of a time limit. But the idea of a time limit was understandably very attractive to people who have been dragged through the debate in fear and uncertainty, not knowing the effect of native title on their futures.

I remind the Senate that we still do not know what native title is at this point. That is the scariest thing for the people in the bush. They have heard Aboriginal leaders say that it ranges from traditional pursuits to economic benefits; from fishing to houses. It is still the great unknown. That is why leaseholders in rural Australia have been so wary of Wik.

Yet we still hear no recognition of this fact in this chamber. Whether it is today, or most of the 89 hours of this debate over the last year or so, the minor parties in the Senate have given no credence to the anguish felt in the bush. It has not been created by the National Party, but by the uncertainty of what native title itself is as described by Aboriginal spokespeople.

It amazes me how Senator Woodley can get up here and describe himself as a friend of the farmers on the one hand and then act totally the opposite when it comes to giving them a fair hearing on native title. The slander and abuse heaped on bush families by minor parties does not bode well for those parties' vote in regional areas.

We have at last reached a beginning on native title. It is only a start and we have to go on with it. We have to work together to get the new arrangements up and running and inject confidence back into the agricultural and mining industries. In earlier debates I have stated that these great industries are our best source of jobs and exports and the best source of a future for Australians.

We have to get these industries right or the national interest will suffer; the interests of small regional towns will suffer; the interests of food and mining process workers in cities will suffer; and the interests of local mill workers in sugar mills and cotton gins will suffer. Black and white families will suffer together in regional Australia unless we get this right and get this beginning working.

That is where the National Party has been coming from in this debate. We have a vision for rural and regional Australia and we must not make the wrong decision now or we will forfeit that vision and this beginning. There remains a possible obstacle, however, in Queensland, and that is the newly elected Labor government. It will be up to them to decide whether to implement the Commonwealth offer of new state arrangements to replace the right to negotiate or to allow the right to negotiate to remain. On pastoral leases this means that Premier Beattie has to choose whether to allow native title holders to have a greater right than the leaseholders on a family farm, for example. In addition, Premier Beattie has to choose whether to change the right to negotiate procedures or see mining companies move south and west where better state regimes are in place. Queensland cannot afford that degree of disinvestment.

The great challenge for the new Premier will be whether he can resist the unrealistic and impractical position on native title as taken by his federal leader, Kim Beazley. We all know that Labor is a highly centralised institution and woe betide any rebellion from the state branches. Queenslanders are in this precarious position because One Nation delivered a Labor government on 13 June. As I stated publicly before the state election, only a Borbidge government could be relied upon to immediately pass state enabling legislation should the native title legislation pass through this parliament. Now that Labor is in power I ask: is Beattie prepared to override the Hobart decision on native title and the right to negotiate? Will Beattie dare to take on his own party's powerful central executive? It does not seem likely at all.

Today Beattie has announced that he is considering a cooperative approach on state native title regimes with New South Wales Labor Premier, Bob Carr. This is a picture of two Labor Premiers getting together to dud farmers. If Beattie is going to be led around by the nose by Bob Carrâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Boswell, please refer to your state parliamentary colleagues by their correct titles and not make any imputations against them.
âI called them two Labor premiers.
âYou have not been using their correct names. You have been referring to them by their surnames only. Please add `Mr'.

âIf the Premier of Queensland, Mr Beattie, is going to be led around by the nose by the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, on native title issues then Queensland leaseholders should be very sceptical indeed. Until an alternative state regime is in place, the right to negotiate will continue to apply on pastoral and former pastoral lease land, and reservations in relation to mining leases and compulsory acquisition. How long will Mr Beattie wait? Is he going to wait forever or is he going to continue to talk with the New South Wales Premier? Regional Queensland does not have very much time left.

speech.para: In conclusion, I say to Senator Harradine that, while the bush may not have got everything it wanted, it certainly got a great deal more than it would have had if there was no legislation there. I acknowledge the anguish and mental stress that he has been through over the last two or three weeks, and I thank him for it.

talk.start.para: âI begin by acknowledging the Ngunnawal people as we again, for the third time, debate this Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] in this place and take another step backwards in the process of understanding and reconciliation with Aboriginal people.

speech.para: We are not going to avoid the issue of race at the next election by what we are going to do over the next two days. We are not taking that issue off the table. Race will be a key issue when we come to the electionâOne Nation will make sure it is on the table.

This bill will now head off to the courts. It will also now go to the states. Some of the decisions will now be made at that level. Those who are supporting Aboriginal people and reconciliation will, hopefully, begin their efforts again at that level to see if they can get some certainty and a solution that is in the best interests of all Australians.

We have postponed an election; we may now not have a double dissolution, but when the half Senate election comes, probably in October, we are going to see that Aboriginality is still a key issue, and that is largely because One Nation will continue to send out a message that is divisiveâan untrue message that Aboriginal people are so well off that somehow they have to be brought back to where non-Aboriginal people are.

This message has gone unanswered by our Prime Minister. As One Nation continues to ignore reality and tap into the urban myths as they call, for example, for the abolition of ATSIC, the removal of Aboriginal affairs departments, the abolition of specific services for Aboriginal people to force them back into the generic services that have proven over the years to be so unsatisfactory and largely ineffective for them, we hear nothing from our Prime Minister. We do not hear him standing up and explaining clearly to the Australian people why specific services are so essential.

Unfortunately, even ministers who do know the facts in their own portfolios have made very few efforts to stand up and undo the damage: to actually put paid to some of those urban myths and to stop the racist bushfire taking off. So I just want to read onto the record today some of the reasons why we should have a government standing up and clearly saying to the Australian people, `The way to support our Aboriginal brothers and sisters is to make sure that they have services that are appropriate for them.'

Let us look at the issue of Aboriginal health. The life expectancy for Aboriginal people is 15 to 20 years less than that of the general population. At any age Aboriginal people are more than twice as likely as non-Aboriginal people to die. Diabetes affects 30 per cent of people in some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, which is four times the rate for non-indigenous people. The infant mortality rate is still more than three to five times higher than that for other Australian children. We have seen through Aboriginal health services significant gains in all of these areas. Indeed, looking at some recent figures from Queensland, we are seeing, through the appropriate delivery of services, that the infant mortality rate has been brought back to the Australian average.

In education, only 33 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children complete secondary school, compared with the national average of 77 per cent. Here, at last, we were also seeing some results through Abstudy. But what was one of the first decisions that this government made? To reduce the support available through Abstudy. I stand here now and say very clearly to the Prime Minister: if you further degrade the services that Abstudy delivers, we will see even fewer Aboriginal people with the opportunity to go through secondary education, let alone get to tertiary education.

Employment is an issue often highlighted by One Nation. But the facts are that the unemployment rate is 38 per cent for indigenous people, compared with 8.7 per cent for the general population.
